problem_text:
As in 17.57, let r(m) = {r + km | k ∈ Z} for integers 0 ⩽ r < m; for r1(m1) ∩ r2(m2) = ∅ let the class transposition τr1(m1),r2(m2) be the involution which interchanges r1 + tm1 and r2 + tm2 for each integer t and fixes everything else, and let CT(Z) be the group generated by all class transpositions.
Let CTk be the subgroup of CT(Z) generated by the class transpositions τr1(k),r2(k) for 0 ⩽ r1 ≠ r2 < k. Since τr1(k),r2(k) permutes the residue classes modulo k, the group CTk is isomorphic to the symmetric group Sk. Let CT(k) = ⟨CT2, CT3, . . . , CTk⟩. Is it true that for k > 3 the group CT(k) is isomorphic to the symmetric group SN, where N is the least common multiple of the numbers 2, 3, . . . , k?
V. G. Bardakov, A. L. Iskra
